name: Código Lyoko
description:
Fantasy game related to the french cartoon TV serie called Code Lyoko.

The players need to collaborate in oder to defeat X.A.N.A., a virus that attacks both the real world and the web world.

Codigo Lyoko uses two boards, cards and dice.

The game goal is to find 4 diary parts, belonging to Franz Hopper, lost in the virtual world. These diary fragments are the clue to fight against the supercomputer called X.A.N.A.

But it is not easy because there are waiting for you hundreds of virtual monsters (counters and cards) and dangers. The players, 1-4, have to face these threaths through the board related with the virtual world moving from level to level. There are 5 levels, each one with different landscapes. The last one is the place where Aelita (one of the main characters), should activate a virtual tower using the Lyoko Code in order to came back to the past.

It is important too to take an eye in the real world (second board) because X.A.N.A. is trying to control the heroes friends in order to win.

Summarizing, the players have to fight against monsters and face dangers using dice, looking for the diary parts moving through the board and bringing Aelita to the 5 level in order to came back to the past.

name: Realm Coins
description:
Realm Coins is a small game played with only coins (25 copper, 25 silver, and 25 gold) and a pouch.  It is a blind bidding game where you bid coins to win more coins.  The goal of the game is to be the first player with a stash valued 40 or higher.

There are special abilities on each side of the three different kinds of coins that will influence how players bid.  The copper coin's sides are a peasant and a boar.  The silver coin's sides are a knight and a gryphon.  And, the gold coin's sides are a crown and a wyvern.

Since all players play simultaneously this game can be used to determine who the starting player of a much larger game will be.  Realm Coins can easily be played in just a few minutes.

name: Pinguini contro Vampiri
description:
Presented at Play 2008 in Modena (Italy), Pinguini Contro Vampiri is a very simple game with rules similar to Uno. The game was sponsorized by AVIS (Associazione Volontari Italiani Sangue), the most important Blood Donors association in Italy, and the objective of the game is educate children to the importance of blood groups.

It contains 55 cards: 48 Penguin cards and 7 Vampire cards.

The first player plays a Penguin card, that shows a blood group and all related blood groups. Following player should play a related card (with the same symbol), otherwise comes in Play a Vampire card, that lightly modify the rules of the game.

If one player has no cards, the game ends and all players has won. If the last Vampire is played, the game ends and all players have lost.

name: Cars 2 World Grand Prix Board Game
description:
Race your favorite character from Cars 2, through Tokyo, Porta Corsa or London. Don't spend too much time in the pits and watch out for oil slicks. Every roll of the dice can affect any player - so you never know who will be first over the finish line.

This game should not be confused with the similarly titled Cars 2: World Grand Prix Board Game by Ravensburger or White Castle

name: JBT Interceptor
description:
Trivia game where players move around the board answering the questions about sports, culture, techincs, history etc.
Correct answers are rewarded with point-cards
Player who accumulates 10 point-cards, must answer the final question to win the game.

name: La Bourre
description:
Racing game of bikers.
The goal is to complete the first ten laps of the neighborhood on the game board first. In his turn player roll the dice and advance the number indicated. There are some obstacles like : radar, traffic lights, ice etc. and some special cards allow to neutralize these to move at full speed

name: BD: le Jeu
description:
The goal of the game is during 9 years (9 rounds of the game board) with two kinds of players - the authors and publishers, to compete or join forces to produce a maximum of comic books, and total and maximum points.

The aim of the authors is to acquire a maximum class while providing a minimum of money.
The purpose of publishers is to acquire as much money while ensuring a minimum of Fame.

The game ends when the first of the two editors has nine full turns of the game board and then the scoring begins where authors calculate their royalites, publisher calculate the books sold etc.

name: Scottyopoly
description:
The object of the game is to gain wealth or influence by owning events and power points/chips which each represent 10,000 protestors at your event.  Wealth & Influence win the game.  Being driven to Poverty produces the loser.

A Monopoly-inspired game for 1-4 players inspired by Wisconsin politics in early 2011.

name: MasterChef
description:
The game of MasterChef as the official game of the TV show!

To become MasterChef game, you have to win as many points as possible before the arrival square is reached by one player. Throughout the journey, players will participate in events related to the world of the kitchen, which will challenge their knowledge and culinary skills!

name: California Trivia
description: A Monopoly type game featuring different colored landing spots which requires answering trivia questions about the state of California. A roll of the dice determined which kind of question had to be answered in order to move on to another space.

name: Opération Bagration 1944
description:
Bagration 1944 is the codename of the Soviet offensive against the Heeresgruppe Mitte (Army Group Centre German). In two weeks, it will largely achieve its objectives, destroying a large number of divisions and opening a gap of 400 km wide in the German front. For the first time, the Wehrmacht can not stabilize the situation. The game covers the first two weeks of the battle. Another will focus on the following weeks. Both are played independently but may be related to a great campaign.

Bagration 1944 is a game for two players, one representing the commander of German forces and the other the commander of Soviet forces. It is played on a map covering the theater of the time. It is divided into hexagons representing 20 km from one side to another. It uses pre-cut cardboard pieces in representing military units that participated in this campaign: the German side of divisions and army corps on the Russian side for the most part. A full game lasts 10 turns, each representing two days of real time.

Ziplock game with:
- one A2-size map
- 192 counters
- 16 pages full color rules (both French and English)
- A quick reference aid
- A german display for operation points
- A soviet display for operation points

name: The BORED Game
description:
BORED is a card game where players seek to make sets of cards:

Three or more of the same number and diffeerent colors;
Three or more of the same color and consecutive numbers;
Five letter cards that spell out B-O-R-E-D.

Shape cards and instructional cards alter the flow of play or the construction and value of sets.

The long-term goal is to earn the five letters BORED on the "scorebored".  Each hand that a player ends by making a B-O-R-E-D set is worth one letter; points accumulated through making numeric sets and straights can be used to buy more letters toward the win.

name: Hunt or Gather
description:
SURVIVE THE WINTER...
Hunt rabbits and squirrels. Fight wolves and boar. Forage for nuts and herbs. Hunt efficiently. Know when to hoard your bounty or race back to the village when the need is greatest. Survive the winter and live another summer.

HUNT OR GATHER...
Hunt or Gather is a fast paced and exciting blend of strategy, memory, and dice rolling fun. Each player gets to control two characters, a hunter and a gatherer. Those characters must pool their resources, because in the end only the weaker of the two counts.

Characters set out from the village, hoping to collect plants or hunt animals. With success, their territory grows making it easier to find the path home. If they fail, they may leave with their life if it's a harmless deer, bunny or squirrel, but death is instant if they roll poorly against a deadly bear, wolf, or boar. Good thing they have a lot of cousins to take their place, so you can set off again and keep playing.

name: Schloss Immermehr
description:
From the publishers website:

For years on end something mysterious happens every year on a snowy winter night: snow is falling and the snowflakes keep falling thicker and faster and the pile of snow slowly turns into a wonderful castle – Castle Evermore.

The snow piles up higher and higher, gradually covering objects up. Can you recognize the different sizes of the growing castle?

Castle Evermore is a different size on each card. If the castle size on one of your own cards fits between two of your opponent’s cards, you are allowed to pinch his cards.

Whoever has the most cards in a row without any gaps lying in front of him at the end of the game is the winner.

name: Gods of Olympus
description:
Gods of Olympus is a Board Game for players aged 12 to adult. The game can be played in 2-6 individual players or teams and it includes a variety of challenges. There are 7 categories of challenges- 5 power challenges -Knowledge, Performance, Visual, Physical, Logical- plus General challenges and Battle challenges. Each category has at least 10 different types of tasks of different difficulty levels and styles.

The game is staged in Ancient Greece when Gods were ruling over the earth and influenced the lives of men.  The players enter the Labyrinth and go towards the center to beat the Minotaur and become Heroes.  On their way, players gather Powers, by completing challenges.  Once they are heroes, they need to go back and get out of the Labyrinth. Only a true God can escape the mythical Maze alive. On their way back they need stronger powers that they gather by completing Hero challenges. The first to escape the Labyrinth is the winner – a God of Olympus.

The story: The Gods of Olympus decided to welcome one human among them as one of their peers. But it cannot be any human. He/she has to be worthy of becoming a God, the best they can find, one who is a true hero and of special character. Each city of Ancient Greece selected their best representative and sent them to participate to the Gods of Olympus Challenge.  Each city selected the bravest, the strongest, the smartest and the most talented citizen to represent them in the Gods Challenge and gain protection of the Gods for their city and the people living in it.

You are the representative of one of the cities of Ancient Greece. As your city representative you will have to enter the Labyrinth, face multiple challenges that require skill, strength, knowledge, reach the Centre of the Labyrinth and face the Minotaur. To reach the centre of the labyrinth you need the 5 magic powers you gain on your way, but you also need luck and a good strategy.  You have to act smart, solve the challenges and move fast inside the labyrinth and out.  On your way, you'll have to avoid dangerous creatures like the Gorgons that can turn you into stone. You may also have to fight your opponents in fair battle, especially if they attack you. Only the first getting out of the labyrinth can become a God of Olympus and anyone can still win the game no matter how advanced the other players are, provided they play smart.

name: All Is Lost to Me: Pavia 1525
description:
Hailed as the first modern battle, Pavia marked the rise of hand-held firearms as a tool of warfare. The arquebus became the bench-mark for an entire species of guns. It offered a wooden stock, shaped to nestle in the shoulder, which now meant a gun could be aimed. Politically, France’s defeat at Pavia changed the balance of power in Europe. As a prisoner, the French king Francis I wrote : “To inform you of how the rest of my ill-fortune is proceeding, all is lost to me save honor and life, which is safe …”
The game map represents the battlefield of Pavia. A hex grid has been superimposed on the map to regulate movement. Each hex represents about 200 yards. The game has 12 turns, each turn representing about 30 minutes. Each combat unit represents from 400 to 800 men or horses or guns.

The game starts with the Spanish army having arrived to relieve the siege of Pavia by the French army. Play is composed of 12 turns. Each turn comprises two identical sequences of phases, one for each player.
Sequence of play
The active player’s turn is organized into the following phases :
a) Out of command check
b) Rally
c) French Commander Initiative Check
d) Movement
e) Passive Player Reaction Movement
f) Defensive Fire
g) Offensive Fire
h) Melee

268 pawns and counters

Game design : Lionel LIRON
Original Counter Art : Lionel LIRON
Counter Design : Ton Cundiff
Box Art : Mike Mirfin
Game Board : Michael W. Kennedy

name: Lucky Dice
description:
Test Your Skill

The Lucky Dice game board is a single card that was included with the Carnival game.  However, the game card is not really necessary to play.

The following items are needed: 

     3 dice (d6)
     a piece of paper
     a pen


Draw a grid on the  paper that mimics the grid on the Lucky Dice game card.  This will be used to score the rows, columns, and 2 diagonals.  The scoring is as follows:

     Doubles = 5 points
     Triples = 10 points
     Straight = 15 points


To play, roll the 3 dice.  Assign the three values to any unused squares within the grid.  Repeat 2 more times until the grid is full.  Add up the scores for the rows, columns, and diagonals to get the total (final) score.

Alternatively, if you have 9 dice available, roll three at a time and just place the dice on the spots within the grid on the Lucky Dice game card.  After all dice have been placed, sum the scores for the rows, columns, and diagonals to get the total (final) score.

name: Race to Tokyo
description:
Issue game in Command Magazine Japan #102

Covering the planned landing in Kanto area, Japan (Operation Coronet) at the end of WW2.
Using the same system as Battle for Germany by SPI.

One player controls the U.S. 1st army landing along Kujuukuri-beach and the Japanese western force.
The other player leads the U.S. 8th army landing along Sagami-bay and the Japanese eastern force.
Each player gains victory points by conquering towns and cities.
Each hex represents 6km.
The game ends at the end of 8th turn.  And each turn is 1 week.

name: Danger Météorites!
description:
Danger Meteorites offers a thrilling adventure in our galaxy.
Each player has four rocket and space probes. The goal is to place these on each of four solar system planets to win .
But there is need to be careful and avoid the crossing meteorites.
Player rolls 1 or 2 dice in his turn. If the wrong face (one of six) appears on dice, he must start at the beginning with all the probes.

name: À l'attaque!!!
description:
Distribute all the cards between the players. Everyone keeps his cards face down in front of him without looking. 
In his turn player turns a card face up in the middle of the table.

If it is a "Gauls", it nothing happens. 
If it is a "Roman", The first who shouts it wins all the cards from the table. He shuffles his cards and continues the play.
If it is "Boar" The first who shouts "Pig"! draws 2 cards from any  any players.

Player who wins all the cards is the winner.

name: Astérix: Le Défi de l'arène
description:
The game board has to be assembled with 4 parts to create a big 3D arena. The race track has twenty-eight boxes of which sixteen are risky: firing a crossbow may shoot a pawn in it at any time.

The same bow determines, according to the box where the ball comes from, how many spaces you advance.

In turn, the player must skillfully position the crossbow to try to remove an opponent's pawns lying on its trajectory. Then he moves his pawn the number indicated by the ball.

name: Sinco
description:
A kind of Lotto for Christmas time. Instead of numbers, the game uses a traditional deck of Neapolitan cards, 40 in all in the traditional Italian-Spanish suits of Clubs, Coins, Cups and Swords. Each player has a mat showing 25 cards making several combinations of 5 cards each. The scores go from the single central card to 5 cards combinations, or Sinco.

The man on the box cover photo, is the designer himself, Emilio Salvatore. The other people are members of his family, daughters, wife and nephew in particular.

name: Mit dem KDF Wagen durch Großdeutschland
description:
Objective: be the first reaching the target & back passage
 - moving by turn -
choose a route  e.g. North-South A: Flensburg-Hamburg-Hanover-Nuremberg-Munich-Vienna 
each player rolls the die - ending on a marked space follow instructions printed on the board (e.g. slow down, roll an odd number, move back...)
after target was reached/passed turn back to starting point
board shows alternative routes 
remarks:
game was published ~ 1940 - at least 2 different editions
inspired by a test drive 1938 done by engineers of VW, comparing the new developed VW with Opel, Ford cars...
meeples: the well known/wanted 'Fröha' cars 
rare collector's item

name: Astérix: Les Baffes
description:
There are 28 cards in this game: 20 "slap" cards + 8 "special" cards.

The object is to provide a maximum of slaps to the Romans!

In his turn player draws a card and keep it face up in front of him.
"Baffes": slap cards - these are the points you earn in battle.
"Banquet" pass the next round, it's time for wild boar!
"Julius Caesar" give your best card "slap" to your neighbor on the right.
"Magic Potion" your neighbor left his cards mixed and makes you draw a card at random!

When all the cards were drawn, each one counts the number of data slaps to the Romans. Whoever has the most slaps won!

name: Cantuun
description:
With a map of Switzerland as board, Cantuun is a call for travel along with four young and curious people, who began a challenge on Facebook: be the first to arrive in canton Uri after having visited each and every Swiss canton. The game pursues two clear  objectives: to add to one's knowledge on what one thinks to know on Switzerland, and to have a good time.
(translated from the french official description)

Cantuun is a trivia game about the cantons of Switzerland. Each player has a set of card representing each Swiss canton, and plays them hidden to answer the questions. Each correct canton selected brings points, and the first player to reach 26 points wins. There are three different types of questions (easy, hard and speed questions), which makes the game more dynamic than a regular trivia game.

name: Green Hell: Burma 1942-1945
description:
Green Hell uses the popular Fire & Movement system (DG Folio Series) to examine two different situations in Burma during World War II: Operation Thursday and The Battle of the Admin Box.

Operation Thursday simulates the British gliderborne assault into Burma in March 1944, after Gen. Slim ordered Gen. Wingate to land behind the Japanese lines to support the Allied offensive in Burma, particularly Gen. Stilwell’s advance to the strategic town of Myitkyina.

The Battle of the Admin Box is a simulation of the Japanese infiltration that surrounded the Indian 7th Infantry Division, and was also moving to trap the Indian 5th Infantry Division in order to annihilate both before the arrival of the Indian 26th and British 36th Divisions from the north. Holding up the entire Japanese plan was the headquarters area of the Indian 7th Division, which formed a defensive perimeter known as the “Admin Box” in the village of Sinzweya.

Game Scale:

        Game Turn: ? days
        Hex: ? mile / ? km
        Units: Company to Regiment (mostly Battalion)


 
Game Inventory:

        One full color map
        One dual-side printed countersheet (160 1/2" counters)
        One rulebook (including Fire & Movement Standard & Burma exclusive rules)


(from the S&T press website)

name: Safari Parc
description: In Safari Park, players try to become expert zoologists. To achieve this, they must travel through the various animal parks and answer the questions about animals and nature. They must choose wisely which parks to visit according to the card objectives that they receive at the beginning of the game.

name: Minden Rose
description:
Wargames Rules for European Battles of the Seven Years War (1756-1763) by Barry Lee

Useable with 10-28mm figures. Covers the Seven Years War and includes 2 Scenarios (Minden and Zorndorf). Units of 3-6 bases/elements with 2-6 Units per Brigade. Includes Army Lists and notes for all protagonists. Playable by 2 or more players per side. Quick Reference Sheet included. Fastplay.


        Rules now available in Free PDF form at MindenRose Yahoo Group**

name: Scavenger
description:
Remember when you were young and you would look out the window on road trips and name off the out-of-state license plates that passed by? What about the different road signs? Scavenger has turned this travel activity into a travel game, perfect for your next road trip.

Scavenger travel games are compact travel tins with magnetic game pieces. Each magnet represents the images (either license plates or road signs) you need to find.

How to play:
Each player receives a travel tin. While traveling look for the license plates or road signs that you still need. Mark off your finds by moving the matching magnets over to the other side. The person who finds the most is the winner.

The game was designed for multiple players but works equally well as a solo game.

name: Fooba-Rou Quarterback Football Game
description: This is a simple spin the spinner game. The spinner has a metal ball that is spun around and where it stops determines the result of the play. You are the quarterback and you can either chose to spin the Running Spinner or try to throw using the Passing Spinner in order to get results for the play. There is also a Extra Point/Kickoff/Field Goal Spinner and a Punt Spinner.

name: Horses
description: A simple betting game where a deck of cards is used to race 4 horses down the track. Method of movement is simply by turning over a card. The suit determines which horse moves. The action comes from betting on which hose will Win, Place and Show.

name: Heist: The Solitaire Card Game
description:
Heist is a solitaire card game in which the player uses his/her con artist to infiltrate companies, houses, banks, etc to complete the given missions.

Players must combine the skills of con men wisely and should be ready for the great heist (last mission of the game)

There are 4 types of cards in the game.

Event Cards: These cards have random events on them and they also have a map piece illustration, which represent the game board. Players draw event cards to create the rooms explained in the plan cards and they also try to resolve the events.

Plan Cards: These are cards with missions on them. Players need to complete at least 3 missions to run the great heist. Every mission needs some skills to be completed.

Con Cards: These are character cards with different skills. Players combine them to complete missions.

Item Cards: These are cards representing various items, helping players to complete missions.

name: Match & Matrimony
description:
In Match & Matrimony you are trying to marry your daughters off during the British Regency era.

The game is played over a number of rounds.  Each round two eligible suitors are available to be won.  Each player secretly chooses a daughter to send in an attempt win over one the suitors.  Each daughter has unique values in 4 attributes, and each suitor has a preference for one attribute.  Some suitors are worth more than others, and in addition players are attempting to collect sets of suitors to increase their worth.

All but one of your daughters will be married by the end of the game, so it is important to choose suitors wisely.  It's not enough to marry your daughters to just anyone.

name: Kette
description:
Paper-and-pencil game where from 2 to 4 players must score the most possible points by filling a row or column of an 8x8 board with their own symbol over several rounds.

During a round players throw a dice in their turn and then tick a space on the board with their symbol (dot, circle, square or cross); the points in the dice mark the distance this space must have to either the player's starting row (at one of the sides of the board) or one of the spaces occupied by the player, and the way to that space must be free (if there are occupied spaces in between they must include the player's own symbol).

When a line is filled with one symbol each player gets a point per own symbol included in the line and the player to end the round gets one extra point. A game includes a number of rounds to be agreed.

name: Livid Visage
description:
Livid Visage is a combat based Card Game where you control a team of characters to defeat your opponents crew. Play events to manipulate the board state and get livid.

Each player constructs a 40 card deck from a set pack that contains all the cards of the game. The game starts with each player putting in to play a character with powers 3,2,1,0 from their deck and as the game progresses each player is allowed to play a new character in their character zones. Each player has 5 character zones in which they can play characters in. Additionally there are Event cards that help players manipulate the board state and acquire an edge over the opponent.

The goal of the game is to defeat all of the opposing characters and leave your opponent with no characters to defend with. When this happens that player loses the game.

name: Saaguan
description:
Saaguan is an abstract strategy game for 2 to 6 players designed by Andrew Cooke, an Englishman living in Yunnan, South China.

The game can be played in an hexagonal board of size 6 or in an octaboard each side 5 squares long. In both boards the outermost ring of the board is called corridor and the inner part is the arena.

Board starts empty.

In each turn, players can:

     Add a triangular piece on the corridor, provided that it has less than 2 of his pieces already in there.
     Move his pieces up to 3 times, being rotating them right or left (45º in the octaboard, 60º in the hexaboard) or advancing one house in the beam direction (pointing vertix). 


A robot is eliminated when it has 3 robots pointing to it (imagine a beam coming out of its pointy vertix). Also, a robot is "locked" (hence can't be moved and its "beam" are disabled) when 2 robots are facing it.

The goal is to be the player who achieves the target score (2 - 6 players) or to eliminate all but 2 of the opponent's robots (2 players). Points are scored when eliminating enemy's robots.

name: Country Music Celebrity Game
description: This game pits players against each other in a country music star setting. The objective of the game is to make it all around the board and arrive in Music City with the most money. Players roll the dice to get to destinations or complete objectives like getting a hit record where each player will either be rewarded or have to pay. "Stars on tour"

name: Leap Frog!
description:
Leap Frog! is a game for 2-4 players. In Leap Frog! each player takes control of a frog in a pond filled with lily pads of varying heights. Players then hop their frogs between lily pads in an attempt to eat a variety of different flies. At the end of the game, each player counts the point value of the flies his or her frog has eaten. The frog that has had the tastiest meal (scored the most points) is the winner.

The movement/hopping mechanic in Leap Frog! uses a small deck of cards, containing distance values between 1 and 4. In order to hop to a lily pad, a player must play a card from his hand equal to the distance of the jump. Leap Frog uses a simple, yet novel, system to determine jumping distance, which takes into account both the number of spaces and the height a frog must jump.

name: Cric Crac Croc
description:
Each player rolls the dice and moves on the course to finish in the home of an animal or the house of all animals.

From the house of all animals, the player chooses the food for the animal of their choice.

When a player arrives at the home of an opponent's animal which has all types of food collected, he can steal chosen food..

Whoever has the most food at the end wins the game.

name: Zip Zap
description:
Game description from the publisher:

Sparks are gonna fly in this lightning-fast card game! In Zip Zap, you want to quickly rid your hand of cards by playing numbers in order. Lay down a run and consider yourself in the zone, but don't get caught ZZZ-ing or else – Zap! – another player will steal the lead! Be the first one out of cards and zero in on the win!

name: Mäuse verstecken
description:
In Mäuse verstecken ("Hiding Mice"), the players take turns hiding two (foam) mice somewhere on their body: in their fist, their knee, elbow, armpit or between their head and shoulder.

The other players have to guess where the mice are hidden. Each player may make two guesses. After all guesses have been made, the active player reveals where the mice are located, and points are scored. A player earns one point for each correct guess. If the location of a mouse has not been guessed by anyone, the player who hid the mouse scores one point. These points are recorded on the scoring track.

After each player has taken a turn hiding the mice, the player who is furthest ahead on the scoring track wins.

name: Fishing Kitty
description:
In Streck dich, Mieze!, the players play cats who are fishing in the river.

At the start of the game, the river is created by marking the riverbanks with two cords. Cards depicting fish worth 1-3 points are scattered in this river.

Now the players take turn fishing. At the start of a player's turn, a cat card is drawn, which shows the position the player must take at the riverbank, and what body part(s) he may use to get a fish (left hand, right hand, left foot, right foot, nose).

When he has taken up position, the player tries to move one of the fish cards to the riverbank. If he succeeds in doing so, he gets to keep the card. If he falls over or uses the wrong body part for fishing, his turn ends without gaining a fish.

After each player has made five fishing attempts, the game ends, and the player with the highest total value of fishes caught wins the game.

name: Ka'lide
description:
"Play one-on-one or in teams as you flick and flip your way to winning the all-new, exciting magnetic game Ka’lide! Flick your magnetic pucks to bend around your opponents’ or flip your pucks over and use their magnetic power to repel your opponent’s pucks off the mat and out of the game. Expertly create puck clusters and you could double, triple and even quadruple your score."

Each player has a stack of magnetic pucks. The object for two (or more people in teams) to take turns flicking the pucks and land them on numbered scoring zones. The strategy is to flip the pucks over when flicking so that they will either pull/adhere to another puck on the field or repel a puck off of a scoring zone. When all pucks have been flicked, each player scores all pucks that are in their scoring zone on the board.

Another way to describe it is head to head magnetic shuffleboard.

name: Klug überlegt
description:
Paper-and-pencil game where from 2 to 4 players must score the most possible points by filling spaces of an 8x8 board; whole rows and columns add extra points.

Each player throws the die in their turn and ticks with their own symbol (dot, circle, square or cross) as many consecutive spaces on one row or column of the board as pips they've thrown; any free space on the whole board can be chosen to start this segment, but no space on the selected segment can be already marked by the player (different symbols can coincide on the same square, though). Dice throws that can't be used are forfeited.

When every space on the board has at least one symbol the game ends; every symbol scores 1 point and every whole row or column scores extra 5 points.

name: The Legend of Zelda: The Hyrule Fantasy
description: Published in 1986 and only within Japan, little is known about this board game version of the popular Nintendo game. Unlike its simplified American counterpart, The Legend of Zelda, this edition appears to replicate the video game as closely as possible. It comes with an overworld map; dungeon tiles; 4 Link pawns in different colors; individual player boards where items, health, money, and tri-force pieces are collected; a die used for attack and defense; and a hefty rulebook.

name: Rigamaroles
description:
In Rigamaroles, players compete over a series of rounds to be the last two players standing. In each round, role chits will be placed in the center of the room. When given the "GO" by the moderator, players race, and grab one chit. That chit determines the role that player will act out. There will always be one other player in the group who is acting out the same role. Each player must find his/her match quickly, link arms, and sit down on the outside of the room to be safe for the next round. In each round, the last two players standing are ELIMINATED! Play continues as such until there are only two players left and those two players are crowned the Rolemasters for that game! Play several games for a full night of laughs!

The game plays quickly. Averaging about one minute per number of players! You can play it with as many players as you wish. In fact, the more the merrier! Unlike other player-elimination games, Rigmaroles is such a blast to watch, and the rounds go so quickly, that nobody minds being eliminated.

Although players must know how to read to play, there is a variant that allows even non-reading children to join in on the fun. So players of all ages will enjoy Rigamaroles!

name: Grisbi
description:
Game description from the publisher:

Grisbi is a very dynamic and entertaining game about encounters between cops and robbers. Each player's goal is to act quickly and – by matching the right pictures – collect all the location cards. Grisbi is not a turn-based game, so being swift is your best weapon. Try not to make any mistakes while matching pictures!

name: Go Hunt
description:
The Go Hunt card game is packed with tons of fun and laughs and is perfect for most any party.  It will be hard to keep your mind out of the gutter while playing or asking for any one of the 16 different hilarious images on the Go Hunt cards.

Goal: To collect the most matching sets, either sets of 2 or 4. You decide on game play.  Matching sets 2 will make for a quicker game, sets of  4 will extend game play.

There are 16 differant card images to play and match: Bald Beaver, Big Cock, Big Honkers, Cuddly Puss, Cute Ass, Dry Puss, Excited Monkey, Fat Beaver, Little Hooters, Fat Weiner, Little Monkey, Nice Rack, Red Pecker, Stretched Puss, Small Cock, Wet Puss.  The images are all innocent pictures of animals, check them out in our picture gallery! No animals were hurt in the making of the Go Hunt card game.

Game play: With four or less players; seven cards are dealt to each player.  Five cards can be dealt to each player in larger groups.  The remaining cards are placed face down in a draw pile.  The player left of the dealer goes first.  On your turn, ask any player for a specific card.  For example: "Michele do you have little hooters?"  You must already hold one of the requested cards.  If Michele has any little hooter cards she must give them all to you.  If the person you ask does not have the card you requested, they would say "Go Hunt!"  You would then draw a card from the draw pile.  When the draw pile runs out, keep playing until all the cards have been made into matching sets.  When you collect a set of matching cards, immediately show the other players and place the cards face down in front of you.

Is is fair to lump all pair matching games together? Yes it has the same type of play as go fish, but the card images really make the game stand out. Playing basketball, and playing a game of HORSE is differant, for example in the game Go Hunt there is a card with an image of a fat beaver eating an apple, the card is called "FAT BEAVER", now imagine this card and 15 others in play, would you ask your grandma if she had a "FAT BEAVER", "WET PUSS" or even a "LARGE COCK".

In conclusion if you have an inoccent soul and a naughty mind you"ll have a blast playing the Go Hunt card game with your friends!

There are also variants of the Go Hunt game that are drinking games, so if your over 21 give them a try!

name: Chivalry
description:
Chivalry is the forerunner of Camelot.  Under development by George S. Parker in 1882, Chivalry was released by Geo. S. Parker & Co. in 1887, and by Parker Brothers in 1888.  Parker called Chivalry "the best game in 2,000 years," and looked upon it as his personal favorite.  Chivalry is played on a larger board with more pieces than Camelot.  Chivalry, like Camelot, is tactically complex, yet easily learned and quickly played.  It is a clever mixture of American Checkers (British Draughts) and Halma (Chinese Checkers).

The goals of the game is to move two pieces into the two goal spaces on the opposite side of the board. Of course, one has to get past the opponent's piece to do so. Movement of pieces in many ways resembles Checkers except that jumping and moving is omnidirectional.

This game tends to be dominated by key sacrifices and charges for the goal. Since a player has to get two pieces into the goal, the dynamic shifts from just trying to get a single piece into a goal. In other words, players won't make one sudden leap to victory; at least a 1-2 punch is required.

For those familiar with Camelot:

Chivalry is different than Camelot in the following ways:

     The Chivalry board has 176 squares.  The Camelot board has 160 squares.  
     Each side in Chivalry has eight Knights and twelve Men.  Each side in Camelot has four Knights and ten Men.

name: Four-handed Chivalry
description:
This four-handed pure abstract has both partnership and individual versions. The object is to capture all opponents' pieces.

Pieces jump like in checkers but in all directions and can jump (without capturing) friendly pieces before capturing any opponents' pieces. So the jumps can become very complex.

Uusually a clear vitor will emerge before the final pieces are atually taken-- but not always.

For those familiar with Chivalry (1888) or Camelot (1930):

Four-Handed Chivalry uses the standard Chivalry board, but is very different in several ways from the standard Chivalry game, as well as from Camelot or any Camelot variant:

1. Unlike all other Camelot variants, only Knights are used.

2. Unlike all other Camelot variants, the solitary object of the game is to capture all opposing Knights; moving Knights into a Castle has no significance.

3. Unlike Grand Camelot, in the partnership version of Four-Handed Chivalry, partners sit opposite each other, and move rotation passes clockwise around the table.

name: Grand Camelot
description:
This game is to Camelot what 4-player chess is to chess. Of course, the set-up, board and gameplay are markedly different than Camelot.

The game is played in partnerships with partners sitting next to each other. The goal is for one set of partners to get any two pieces to te opponents' goal spaces-- either each partner getting one piece into one of the two the goal spaces opposite him or one partner getting two pieces into those spaces.

Each player has two types of pieces which mostly move similarly. Draughts-like jumps occur in all directions, or one can jump one's own pieces without capturing. Each player focuses on trying to get his pieces past the player opposite him BUT defense also has to protect the opponent from pieces moving laterally.

Note that Grand Camelot is distinctly different from the other 4-player games in the Series: Camelot (Abstract games) family, Four-handed Chivalry and Grand Cam.

name: Cam
description:
Cam is a small but not tiny game of sudden death. This little abstract ends as soon as one player gets any one piece to the single goal space at the opposite end of the board. To do so, one has to get past the opponent's pieces.

Each player has two types of pieces which mostly move similarly. One can jump one's own pieces or jump to capture an opponent's. Multiple jumps in any direction are allowed. So, sudden reversals and leaps to victory are not uncommon. Since only one piece in the goal is needed to win, this game can be unforgiving. Still it's quick and many games can be played in one sitting.

Cam, released by Parker Brothers in 1949, is a down-sized version of Camelot.

Cam is different than Camelot in the following ways:

    The Cam board has 67 squares.  The Camelot board has 160 squares.
    Each side in Cam has two Knights and five Men.  Each side in Camelot has four Knights and ten Men.  
    The object of Cam is to get one piece into the opponent's Castle.  The object of Camelot is to get two pieces into the opponent's Castle.  
    Victory in Cam also occurs if one side, even with only one remaining piece, captures all of the opposing pieces.  In Camelot, if the side capturing all of the opposing pieces has only one remaining piece, the game is a draw.  Victory in Camelot by capture of all of the opposing pieces occurs only if the victorious side has two or more remaining pieces.    
    Stalemate in Cam is impossible.  Stalemate in Camelot is possible, and is a victory for the stalemating side if it has two or more pieces.  
    In Cam, if both sides have only one remaining piece, the game continues until one piece captures the other, or one piece enters the opposing Castle.  In Camelot, if both sides have only one remaining piece, the game is a draw.


Re-implements:

    Chivalry
    Camelot

name: Camette
description:
Camette is a pure two-player abstract played on a very small board. Hence it plays very fast, especially since the object is to get any one piece onto an opponent's goal space-- which  that player canot occupy himself. As in all games of this family, there are two different types of pieces which mostly move similarly. Pieces can jump over friendly pieces and jump over enemy pieces to capture them. With a board this small, sudden leaps to victory are common.

For those familiar with Camelot (1888):

Camette is a down-sized version of Camelot, even smaller than Cam, with a further reduced board size and number of pieces.  Camette was invented by Michael Wortley Nolan in 2002.

Camette is different than Camelot in the following ways:

1. The Camette board has 23 squares.  The Camelot board has 160 squares.

2. Each side in Camette has one Knight and three Men.  Each side in Camelot has four Knights and ten Men.

3. The object of Camette is to get one piece into the opponent's Castle.  The object of Camelot is to get two pieces into the opponent's Castle.

4. Victory in Camette also occurs if one side, even with only one remaining piece, captures all of the opposing pieces.  In Camelot, if the side capturing all of the opposing pieces has only one remaining piece, the game is a draw.  Victory in Camelot by capture of all of the opposing pieces occurs only if the victorious side has two or more remaining pieces.

5. Stalemate in Camette is impossible.  Stalemate in Camelot is possible, and is a victory for the stalemating side if it has two or more pieces.

6. In Camette, if both sides have only one remaining piece, the game continues until one piece captures the other, or one piece enters the opposing Castle.  In Camelot, if both sides have only one remaining piece, the game is a draw.

name: Grand Cam
description:
Grand Cam is a four-player analog of the game Cam. This is a partnership pure abstract game. Partners sit next to each other. To win, one player has to move a piece into the goal opposite his pieces' starting position or all the losing partnership's pieces must be captured.

This has the marked differences in play between Camelot and Cam combined with two pairs of immediate opponents whose pieces generally move in directions orthogonal to each other.

The design of the Grand Cam piece setup and the design and construction of the first Grand Cam game board in 2005 owe themselves to WCF member Paul Bramwell Smith, who is deservedly acknowledged as the game's inventor.

Grand Cam is different than Grand Camelot in the following ways:

1. The Grand Cam board has 93 squares.  The Grand Camelot board has 180 squares.

2. Each side in Grand Cam has two Knights and five Men.  Each side in Grand Camelot has four Knights and eight Men.

name: Tri-Camelot
description:
Ostesibly a 3-handed analog of Camelot, this game bares some resemblance to Cam in that it has a single goal each player must protect. Additionally the board is markedly different than any game in the Camelot family and uses hexagons.

The game is a three-handed pure abstract. Each player protects a single goal space from both opponents. In spite of the name, this game is a three-handed version of Cam, not Camelot in that the first first to enter a goal wins and so ends the game. Often this means that a player can block one but not both opponents. Hence these games can end suddenly and kingmaking can be involved.

name: Word Twist
description:
Word Twist is a game for two teams.  Teams take turns drawing a card from the deck which will display one of five categories, some of which incorporate elements from other well-known word games.  The categories are:


     Nonsense - players have to answer a question on acronyms, dates, words, people or movies;
     Word Bluff - players have to identify the correct definition of a word from three possible choices;
     Express Yourself - players give clues to get their teammates to identify a word, but cannot say certain banned words;
     Word Twist - both teams compete to make as many smaller words as possible from the letters of a given word;
     Memory Time - a short passage is read from the card and questions are then asked to the opposing team.


Teams accrue points in each round and the winner is the team with the most points after a predetermined number of rounds.

From the box front: Word Twist: Every Word Game You've Ever Played - In One!

name: Spillway
description: A 2-player abstract game created for the Shibumi Challenge. Players attempt to connect opposite sides of the board with their color, but doing so clears all of your marbles out of the spillway!

name: Animaux et Réserves de France
description:
Attractive trivia game, centred around the players' knowledge of animals within the regions of France. The six areas deemed to have these animals resident in them, are Vanoise, Corse, Pyrénées, Camargue, Armorique and Lorraine.

Each player receives animal tiles which act like jigsaw puzzle pieces i.e. they fit onto the board thus filling the map-board of France. To place a piece you must answer a question correctly. The questions, of course, are related to the subject of the game. First to place all their pieces, wins.

name: Feu Rouge Feu Vert
description:
Educational game about identifying road signs and observing road safety.

The track is ingeniously designed, going over and under itself at key points. Movement is by dice. At certain points on the track you must answer a question. The answer is hidden from you but if you place a transparent device over it, it becomes visible. You must get a question right to proceed. The first player to reach the end of the track, wins

name: Géorami
description:
Educational game about the geography of France. It has a board showing all the separate regions of the country, but it is really a card game,

Three 'Contracts' are revealed. The contract might say "Regions that begin with the same letter", that sort of thing. Each player has 10 cards and can claim a contract if you reveal the cards asked for. Each contract is worth points - easy to do might be 3 points, more difficult 6 points, very difficult 10 points. When a contract is taken another one replaces it.

The first player to obtain 10 contracts scores the points on each contract, plus two points for each contract that another player has less then ten, plus 20 points for going out first. The player with the highest score, wins.

name: Nouns in a Bag
description:
A party game where teams take turns trying to guess nouns or phrases being described in increasingly limited fashion by a teammate.

At the beginning of the game each player writes five nouns or phrases on a slip of paper, which are all then shuffled into a bag.  Players are divided into two teams, and one team is chosen to start.  It is recommended the starting team alternate between rounds to reduce the starting advantage.

The first round is timed for 1 minute.  The active team chooses someone to draw nouns from the bag, while the rest of the team tries to guess the noun.  During this round the active player may say anything they like, as long as they do not say the words on the paper.  Each correct guess is worth a point.  Then, with all the drawn papers left out of the bag, the second team does the same.

The second round is timed for 2 minutes, and is played as the first round, except instead of speaking the active player may only perform charades.

The third round is timed for 1 minute, and is identical to the previous two except now the active player may only say one word.

name: Über Land und Meer
description:
Objective: find as many of wanted nations/capitals as possible

- acting by turn/simple 'draw & place' geographic game -

Flip tiles upside down
Draw a tile (flag/capital) and find the corresponding place on the map(s)
6 different maps Africa, Asia, Australia and Oceania, Europe, North America & Central America, South America.
Remarks: 
Version held by National Library of Australia dated 1890s. 
The individual maps were subsequently updated, another version having maps showing borders as follows: South America ~ 1905, Africa ~ 1885, Europe ~ 1920.

name: The Human Race
description:
Earth - Present Day
The day started off so well for the humans, but then the sky darkened as a higher intelligence showed its face. These aliens are here to have a little fun, it's a race-to abduct the most humans. Can the humans strike back, or will the aliens have their way?

The Human Race is a competitive alien abduction game, a cooperative military defensive game, or both!

Alien Abduction
You and your alien opponents must move your spaceship pawns around the hex-filled game board to abduct the specific human target as indicated by the deck of target cards. While a player is abducting a human, opponents may move on to the next target or try to steal the human abductee from the alien abductor by attacking them. But look out! The humans aren't going to take this sitting down, the military is after you too. There are also bonuses to help you along on your journey. The alien with the most points when all the humans have been abducted wins!

Military Defensive
You will control the Earth denizens in a last-ditch effort to keep your peeps safe! Blast the heck out of the alien menace and end their sick game once and for all. Move jets and tanks around the board in order to quell the situation while moving human targets to safety. Rob the aliens of their prizes or their spaceships and save the day!

name: Eisenbahn-Spiel
description:
Objective: be the first reaching target space
 - moving by turn - 
simple 'Roll & Move' game
roll the die - ending on a marked space draw a card and follow instructions
remarks
huge board: 49 x 71.5 cm (19.3" x 28.1")
cover shows 3 well known mountains: Eiger, Mönch, Jungfrau.

name: The Hunt: Carpathia, 1897
description:
The Hunt: Carpathia, 1897 is a period specific tabletop adventure game, set in the dangerous monster-ridden land of Carpathia.

Players of The Hunt will take turns moving around the game board, fighting monsters, avoiding hazards, collecting bounties, and trying to kill one another - all while trying to find better weapons and gear.  Ultimately they want to take down one of the unique Prey monsters, each of whom grants a unique ability to their vanquisher.

Weapons, items, monsters and hazards are all represented on detailed cards with unique art relevant (we hope) to the time period.  Players roll dice (d8) to move and attack, using their own special abilities and items to their best advantage.  Each player is one of 6 unique characters, each with different strengths.

Death in The Hunt is by no means final - when a player loses all vitality points (players start with and have a max of 3) he/she is turned into a "cursed" player, remains on the board with new abilities, and is now turned against the remaining live players.  Nobody is ever "out of the hunt."

Players battle monsters and each other earning trophy points for each monster vanquished.  A player must collect a certain number of trophy points and make it back to the ship for the win!  If all players become cursed, the cursed player with the most trophy points wins.

name: Sopranos Trivia in a Box Board Game
description:
This is the sequal to The Sopranos Trivia Game.

How well do you know Tony and the family? Yo, you betta know deez guys good if youz are gonna play. Now you and your friends can test your knowledge of the number one show on cable with The Sopranos Trivia Game. There are one thousand trivia questions that will challenge you on your knowledge of the program and "Mob Speak". Place bets on which questions you can answer correctly. Five levels of difficulty make it easy for even occasional viewers to play against dedicated fans of The Sopranos.

Game Includes: Vinyl Playing Surface 200 Trivia Cards Betting ChipsFor 2 or more adult players ages 18 and up.

name: Sploink
description:
The first dexterity game using the Shibumi set!

Players roll their marbles onto the board (using paper as a ramp) to score points and multipliers.

Who can Zing the pyramid?

(Note, it is recommended to play this only with the Ninja set. Game may damage marbles from the Samurai set.)

name: Play Trays Sound & Sort Game
description: Sound/picture matching game for 1 or 2 players. Players pick picture tiles and must deduce the first letter of the matching word.  Supplied with non-competitive rules.

name: Heinz Monopoly Game
description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

Another in the very long line of MONOPOLY Games.

name: River Plate
description:
A Naval Game, British made with Prov Pat No 2649. "River Platte". produced by Victory Games during World War II. Features a large scaled down model of a ship along with some miniature ships in different colors used by the players as player pieces. Also is sort of a search board numbered from 1-100 where different spaces might produce attacks by the enemy.

From Ebayer daviddunne who I have contacted for more info about the game

name: Tru-Action Electric Horse Race Game
description: By Tudor. Game features vibrating base turned on by electricity. Line the horses up and watch them race around the track to see who crosses the finish line first. Bet on who wins the race.

name: Major League Baseball Game
description: By GABRIEL from the 1950's. A game featuring spinners and 6 plastic men. Spin the spinner to see what happens in the game

name: Zentrum
description:
Paper-and-pencil game where from 2 to 4 players must score the most possible points by filling the 16 central spaces of an 8x8 board.

Each player starts from a corner of the board and marks with their own symbol (dot, circle, square or cross) a square two or three spaces away in a straight vertical or horizontal line from the square previously marked; a square can be marked by all players. The distance from one marked square to the next has got to be two squares on one turn, three in the next one, then two squares again, then three and so on (the player can choose which value goes first). A player can't land on a square already marked with their symbol.

The game ends when the 16 central squares of the board have been ticked. Players score for the central squares they have ticked: each square brings as many points as different symbols have been marked on the square.

name: Munch
description:
Munch is a game about giant space monsters breaking into our dimension to eat worlds. Monsters also munch each other when they meet while floating through space.

Five Rainbow stashes of Looney Pyramids are required for two players to play. An additional Xeno stash allows up to four players. The game is played on a 6x6 board.

Players take turns placing worlds on the board. At any point players can unleash one of their monsters from their army to the board. Monsters continue to move on the board until they run out of worlds to munch or until they get munched themselves.

The goal of the game is to collect the most worlds, with single-colored trios scoring highest. The player with the highest score from trios and single worlds at the end of the game wins.

name: Spack
description:
Spack is a two-player game for the Shibumi set.

The board is initially empty. Each player ownes 24 balls (8 white, 8 black, 8 red)

Players take turns adding one of their balls. 
Under certain conditions, they can return balls to their supply too.

The game ends, as soon as a player can´t make a legal move.

The winner is determined by the number of balls, the players have left.

Spack is an entry in the Shibumi Challenge.

name: Narrspelet
description:
Old cardgame published in Sweden probably in the 40s or 50s.

You try to complete pair of two cards by taking one card from your neighbour. If you get a pair you put down the cards infront of you. The first one who get rids of all the cards win.

name: Tims Tüftel-Team
description:
The gift machine has broken down and has to be repaired! This is done by connecting the machine parts with a line of dominoes (standing up, so that they can be toppled, not lying down).

At the start of Tims Tüftel-Team, several cardboard tokens representing the machine parts are scattered along the table. The game is played in rounds; in each round, two tokens have to be connected. At the start of the first round, one token is selected as the starting token, and this also dictates which token will be the destination token. In later rounds, the destination token from the previous round becomes the starting token.

Now, the players take turns placing dominoes in the line from the start token to the destination token, building past any other tokens. Each turn, a player rolls a die, which allows him to add zero to three dominoes to the line. When the destination token is reached, the round ends. The player whose turn it is gets to topple the dominoes by pushing the first domino in the line. First, though, the other players have to predict whether or not the entire line of dominoes will fall.

After predictions have been made, the first domino is toppled. If the entire line falls, then the toppling player receives a gift token, as well as any player who made the right prediction; if some dominoes remain standing, the players who predicted that receive a gift token.

After six rounds, the game ends, and the player who has gained the most gift tokens wins.

In the expert version of the game, various contraptions for connecting two lines of dominoes are included, and in each round, one of these is included in the line of dominoes connecting the start and destination.

name: Das Bibel Quiz
description:
Objective: improve your knowledge about the Bible - Old & New Testament
 - acting/moving by turn -
roll the die, move, draw a card, get the correct answer

name: Das Quiz der Schlager & Volksmusik
description:
Objective: move to finish line knowing correct answers on questions out of the world of German Schlager music
 - moving/acting by turn -
roll the die, move forward, draw a correspondent card, find correct answer (out of 4 - multiple choice); questions like (samples):
Andrea Berg was married with? Adamo - which nationality? 
Flippers, Peter Alexander, Kastelruther Spatzen ... songs, text

content: 1 board - 2 different maps, 110 cards, 6 meeples, 2 Joker-meeples, 1 die, rules

name: Josef und seine Brüder
description:
Objective: learn as much as possible about the story of 'Josef', written in the Old Testament;
improve your knowledge, communication, memory...
- acting by turn -
During your turn draw a card and follow instructions ==> you have to tell a story either by drawings, pantomimic,... explaining terms like 'wine', 'christening', 'Adam' in a way that all others can guess successfully what you've tried to describe. 
successful - next players turn
otherwise draw a new card
remarks:
often an adult/game master reads a story prior to the start or at least supervises the activity

name: Suomirokkia trivia 2
description:
A trivia game about Finnish rock music from the 70's to 00's. The game includes a four-piece game board, 1000 questions, 30 pictures and a cd. The cd contains music samples. The publisher is a Finnish record company.

Players answer a question from their space and can advance if they answer correctly. A maximum of 2 advancements in one turn.

name: Pferdekoppel
description:
Paper-and-pencil game where from 2 to 4 players must move on an 8x8 board as Chess knights - used spaces will be unavailable for the rest of the game. The last player who's able to move wins. It's more or less an adaptation of Alex Randolph's Knight Chase for several players.

Each player has got an own symbol (dot, circle, square, cross) and starts from one corner on the board; before anyone moves each player will fill in a square on the board, which will be unavailable from then on (it's not allowed to block a player before their first move). Players then move in turn following the rules for a Chess knight, ticking the corresponding free space on the board with their symbol and filling in the square they departed from. If a player can't move the turn will be forfeited. The last player who can move wins the game.

name: At Neuve Chapelle
description:
At Neuve Chapelle provides a tactical re-play of the World War I battle. The British attempted to reduce a poorly-defended German salient centered on the town of Neuve Chapelle. Plans were to expand a breakthrough and with cavalry and infantry reserves take the Aubers ridge line. However, poor communication and coordination and the weather conspired to slow the initial British successes and allowed the German army to rush reinforcements into the area. Among other game features, designer Michael W. Kennedy uses offensive artillery and defensive artillery fire, British command checks, and a unique assault combat mechanic to simulate the bloody struggle. (Sourced from the White Dog Games website.)

The game is played over a series of 14 turns which represent the three days of The Battle of Neuve Chapelle. Each day is divided into four turns with a separate night turn in between. During the day turns, both sides will fire artillery (weather permitting), move, and attack. During the night turns, both sides will dig in new trenches on the new front lines.

The game simulates early trench warfare and makes prominent use of artillery and the defensive advantages of trenches. Weather conditions and British communications among the four divisions are determined randomly each turn. Each assault phase contains a defensive artillery and defensive combat phase, making defense a major component of the game.

There are several hexes that have victory point values. The British win by controlling as many of these hexes as possible. The Germans win by preventing the British from achieving this objectives.

name: The One True King
description:
The King is dead and three powerful Lords vie for the throne. They will use everything in their power to win (Military Power, Allies, Knights, Nobles, Spies, the church, mercenaries, whatever it takes). Although 3 contend for the crown, in the end there can only be ONE TRUE KING!

In the game, each player plays out 3 columns of cards consisting of Knights, Nobles, Allies, and Army units.  The total strengths of the columns are compared.  Then, Intrigue Cards are played to change the balance of power.  Intrigue Cards include assassinations, bribery, desertions, reserves, etc. The final column strengths are revealed and the player who wins 2 of the 3 columns is the victor.

name: Overkill: Last Man Standing
description:
Overkill: Last Man Standing is a board game about space ships, guns and blood! The players control a spaceship crew fighting against the invaders.

This game has a deck of cards, four dice, eight paper figures, a game board and the rulebook.

Each player controls four soldiers lost in a space station. Every turn, you move your soldiers in the game board, finding items (by buying cards) and fighting the other players in order to survive. 
There is three missions: Steal data (Capture the flag), Invasion ( Time race ) and Overkill (Last Man Standing). In each mission you need to remake your strategy to win.
